segments.text: There was music from my neighbor’s house through the summer nights. In his blue gardens men and girls came and went like moths among the whisperings, champagne, and stars. At high tide in the afternoon I watched his guests diving from the tower of his raft, or sunning themselves on his beach while motorboats sliced through the Sound. Weekends saw his Rolls‐Royce transforming into an omnibus and his station wagon darting to meet arriving trains. And on Mondays eight servants worked all day, restoring the ravages of the night before. Every Friday crates of oranges and lemons arrived from New York, only to be transformed into pulpless halves by a kitchen machine at the press of a butler’s thumb. At least once a fortnight, a team of caterers would descend with canvases and colored lights to transform Gatsby’s enormous garden into a surreal, festive world. Buffet tables overflowed with hors d’oeuvre, hams, salads, and pastries, and the hall’s brass rail bar overflowed with gins, liquors and curios cordials. By seven o’clock the full orchestra arrived—an entire pit of woodwinds, brass, drums and strings—and soon the garden became a riotous swirl of primary colors, modern haircuts, extravagant shawls, and a constant chatter of introductions and innuendo. As twilight deepened, the orchestra shifted to yellow cocktail music and voices pitched a key higher; laughter, light chatter, and the excited mingling of confident wanderers marked the birth of the party.

segments.text: Reading over what I have written so far, I recognize that what seemed like absorbing, events spanning three nights were in fact merely casual episodes in a crowded summer. For much of the time I worked—the early morning rush to the Probity Trust, lunch among familiar clerks on pig sausages and mashed potatoes, and evenings of solitary study in the Yale Club library or long walks through New York’s neon twilight. There were fleeting romances and quiet observations of the city’s restless pulse. In that enchanted metropolitan dusk I even fancied following a few unknown, attractive women just to imagine I might slip into their secret lives.

segments.text: I began to sense, in the soft melancholy of midnight on Fifth Avenue and among the throngs of cabs bound for the theater district, a sinking loneliness even as lively voices and lighted cigarettes swirled around me. And then, sometime later in midsummer, I found Jordan Baker again. Our companionship, initially flattering because of her fame as a golf champion, soon became something more complicated—a blend of tender curiosity and the recognition of her incurable dishonesty. I recalled a rainy day at a house-party in Warwick, a small scandal over a misplayed golf ball, and the secret shifts in our conversation that hinted at deeper emotional divides. All the while, I maintained my modest claim: I am one of the few honest people I have ever known.
